thread.title: Lawmakers pile on to demand answers for Flynn leaks
thread.title_full: Lawmakers pile on to demand answers for Flynn leaks | Washington Examiner

author: Daniel Chaitin
title: Lawmakers pile on to demand answers for Flynn leaks
text:
Two top Republicans are asking the Justice Department's internal watchdog for an   information following leaks that led to the resignation of President Trump 's national security adviser, Michael Flynn.
In a letter written to DOJ Inspector General Michael Horowitz on Wednesday, House Oversight Committee Chairman Jason Chaffetz and House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte write, "We have serious concerns about the potential inadequate protection of classified information here."
They said recent news reports, detailing classified information via unnamed sources, are cause for concern. This includes a report on how DOJ's National Security Division applied for a warrant from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to intercept electronic records from a Russian bank.
Details on the U.S. intelligence community monitoring Flynn's call with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak were also leaked. Another report describes a meeting between then-Acting Attorney General Sally Yates and White House Counsel Donald McGahn over concerns about Flynn's vulnerability to blackmail after he lied to the Trump officials about his communications Kislyak on sanctions before the inauguration.
Subscribe today to get intelligence and analysis on defense and national security issues in your Inbox each weekday morning from veteran journalists Jamie McIntyre and Jacqueline Klimas.
  the Daily on Defense newsletter.   issue soon! Flynn resigned from his post on Monday amid the growing scandal.
Chaffetz and Goodlatte aren't the only lawmakers looking for answers Wednesday.
A letter from Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, and ranking member Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., reached out to Attorney General Jeff Sessions and FBI Director James Comey, requesting a DOJ briefing and any documents relevant to the Flynn situation.
Recent media reports leading up to Flynn's regisignation "raise substantial questions about the content and context of Mr. Flynn's discussions with Russian officials, the conclusions reached by the Justice Department and the actions it took in response, as well as possible leaks of classified information by current and former government employees," they wrote.
"Accordingly, we request that individuals with specific knowledge of these issues from both the FBI and Justice Department brief Committee Members and staff," they continued. "We similarly request copies of the transcripts of Mr. Flynn's intercepted calls and the FBI report summarizing the intercepted calls referenced in the media."
  Report: Intel agencies repeatedly withheld info from Trump Agencies decided to keep sensitive information from Trump out of concern he or his staff would leak it.
By Anna Giaritelli • 02/15/17 9:35 PM The Trump administration has also said it will launch an investigation into the leaks pertaining to Flynn's communications with Russia.
"The president clearly is upset about this, and understands the threat they pose to our national security," White House press secretary Sean Spicer told reporters Tuesday.
Trump's administration has been plagued by a number of questionable national security practices in its first few weeks, prompting condemnation and demand for accountability from both sides of the aisle.
Earlier this week, on Tuesday, Chaffetz wrote another letter , this one addressed to Trump's chief of staff, Reince Priebus, to answer for the various reports and social media posts that claimed Trump, during dinner with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, took a call on his phone on North Korea's test of an intermediate-range ballistic missile, while sitting at a table in a crowded dining room at the Palm Beach, Fla., resort Saturday evening.
Trump then huddled with then-national security adviser Michael Flynn and chief strategist Steve Bannon, while they poured over documents and made phone calls on the situation, according to CNN . First lady Melania Trump and Abe's wife, Akie, were also seated at the table.
  DHS: Gang affiliation of Seattle immigrant cancels DACA status A Seattle man was taken into custody when immigration officials arrested his previously-deported father.
By Anna Giaritelli • 02/15/17 7:54 PM Chaffetz asked the White House to further explain what precautions, beyond the use of a sensitive compartmented information facility, were taken to protect any sensitive information. The letter, which was carbon copied to ranking member Elijah Cummings, D-Md., asks for a response as soon as possible, but no later than Feb. 28, two weeks from now.
"While the president is always on duty, and cannot dictate the timing of when he needs to receive sensitive information about urgent matters, we hope the White House will cooperate in providing the committee with additional information," Chaffetz said.

By Anna Giaritelli • 02/15/17 9:35
